newsitem.title: UK: Lasmo more bullish on find than Pakistan.
newsitem.headline: Lasmo more bullish on find than Pakistan.

text.p: Lasmo Plc said on Tuesday that it newly discovered gas field in Pakistan had estimated reserves of about two trillion cubic feet (tcf).
The announcement follows a more cautious statement by the Pakistani government, which on Monday said estimated reserves were more than one trillion cubic feet.
Lasmo, which made the find in the Kirthar Concession and evaluated the results, said the difference stemmed from a more conservative risk assesment by Pakistan.
"There is a lot of uncertainty, but the mid-point in our view is two tcf. We think the Pakistan government is very conservative," a Lasmo spokesman told Reuters.
Reserves of two tcf would translate in a share for Lasmo of about 130 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, which is about twice Lasmo's 1996 production, the spokesman added.
"This is in potential a significant discovery," he said. "It also adds value to the remainder of the Kirthar concession and also the adjacent concession which we were awarded in January."
Lasmo still has to do seismic research and more drilling before actually booking any reserves. But some reserves might already be booked by the end of this year.
"The two trillion may turn out to be one or it may turn out out to be significantly more. By next year we should have a much clearer view," the spokesman said.
A decision whether to develop the field may be taken in 1999, while the first production might come on stream in 2001 if all goes smoothly, he said.

Lasmo and Shell Exploration Pakistan BV both have a 47.5 percent working interest in Kirthar. Pakistan's state-owned Oil and Gas Development Corporation has 5.0 percent, but has the right to back in for 20 percent.
